I see that first person (for the spacecraft) images are low quality. I am assuming that we will start with bad cameras but then get better and better cameras as the game progresses. Am I right?

Yep. What you see there is near the upper end of the technology, the best you'll be able to get is a comparable level of grain, less bloom, and 24fps video (if you choose to enable the fps reduction, it's not for everyone)
Well my laptop has natural fps reduction!

Made a general purpose noise generator for meshes. Currently used for temporary planet terrain, later will be reused to generate random asteroids and other detritus.

Tomorrow the terrains will gain proper collision, right now they're only using sphere primitives.

Some more pictures, fixed some problems with it and altered the generation parameters. I'm happy enough with this that I think the voxel system can wait a while...

The atmospheres look a little too sharp. I think just a sort of haze effect similar to what is seen in Prototype Zero would be more effective. Right now they look like transparent shells, and it just looks a bit too janky.

The atmospheres look a little too sharp. I think just a sort of haze effect similar to what is seen in Prototype Zero would be more effective. Right now they look like transparent shells, and it just looks a bit too janky.

I am aware. The atmospheres in P0 were actually particle effects. For now I might do something similar, but eventually it will need to be a volumetric looking shader. And, if possible (though unlikely), make it so terrain features cast shadows through the atmosphere.

OK, I'm not quite sure what I'm supposed to do. It would help if there was a way to tell if you were orbiting something or not. As it is, I've been trying to ram planets with no luck.

As was pointed out before, orbits are next to impossible, because

1) The planets are stationary, meaning their gravity tugs are consistent rather than periodic.

2) The planets are building sized, making tidal effects a Kraken to deal with.
